title: I Had No Idea What Soroban Was – Now I Get Why Parents Swear By It
description: I'd never heard of Soroban until other parents kept mentioning it. Here's what I learned after researching and trying it with my kid.
imageAlt: Child learning mental math with Soroban abacus

content.intro: First time I heard "Soroban," I thought: "What's that?" I had no clue what it was or why so many parents were putting their kids in Soroban classes. After digging into it, I finally get it – and I want to share what I found.

sections.text: Simply put: Soroban is the Japanese abacus. It's like the bead calculators our grandparents used, but with a different design that makes it faster.
It has columns, each with 5 beads: 1 bead on top (representing 5) and 4 beads below (each worth 1). Kids slide beads up and down to calculate.
Here's the cool part: After practicing with a physical abacus, kids start visualizing it in their heads and do mental math – that's called "Anzan" or mental Soroban.
My kid was learning math the traditional way – memorizing facts, doing worksheets – but wasn't really understanding. She could recite "7 + 8 = 15" like a song, but couldn't actually picture why.
When I read about Soroban, I saw a different approach: kids "see" numbers through images. I thought: maybe this could click better for her?
After researching, here's what stood out:

items: **Visual learning:** Kids see bead positions to understand numbers, not just memorize
**Builds focus:** Moving beads correctly requires concentration
**Develops mental math:** The end goal is calculating in your head without the abacus
**Great for young kids:** Ages 6-10 are in a prime stage for visual thinking – learning through images comes naturally

sections.text: **"Will it confuse her with school math?"** – I worried about this too. But Soroban doesn't conflict with school math. It's a different approach that actually complements what she's learning.
**"I don't know Soroban – how can I help her?"** – This was my biggest worry. Turns out, I didn't need to know it. The Sorokid app guides her step by step. I just need to be there for support.
**"How much time does it take?"** – About 15-20 minutes daily. Not a lot, but consistency matters.
If you're wondering like I was, don't worry. You don't need to understand everything about Soroban to let your kid try it. What matters is seeing if it's a good fit.
How It's Going for My Kid
I had her try the Sorokid app. The first week was awkward – everything was new. But she got the hang of it. What she loves most is "leveling up" after each lesson.
After about a month, I noticed she's doing mental math faster. Simple problems like 23 + 15? She does them in her head now. Before, she needed to write them out.
I'm not saying Soroban is magic. But for us, it's been a better way for her to connect with numbers. That's worth something.

faq.question: Is Soroban the same as Chinese abacus?
faq.answer: Similar concept, but Soroban (Japanese) has fewer beads per column, making it faster. Chinese abacus has 2 beads on top and 5 below, while Soroban has 1 and 4.

faq.question: Do I need to buy a physical abacus?
faq.answer: It helps to have one for tactile learning, but apps like Sorokid include virtual abacuses that work well too. A physical one costs around $10-15.
